Your statement that the fuel pushing on the nozzle and combustion chamber is what propels the rocket is pretty false. The vast majority of thrust is generated by the expulsion of the exhaust fumes at large mass flow rates. The divergent section of the CD nozzle also speeds up the exhaust, because at supersonic speeds, an expanding cross-sectional area increases velocity, the opposite of how the gases behave at subsonic speeds.

This increased velocity increases the mass flow rate of the exhaust gases, which increases the thrust force.

the reason of it not showing any intresting things when you narrowed up the throat was the
1) the combustion chamber or the place before the throat where reaction was happening was way to big and thus there was not much pressure built up to fire through the main nozzle
2) the throat to nozzle ratio largely matters when you deal with bell nozzle engines here the nozzle was way to big and what happened was the pressure in the chamber dropped too low and thus causing the the air to come in from outside which slowed the reaction and thrust. this is why the flames was not close to the walls (glass)
3)the shape of the part after throat was not well for fluid mechanics. if you see very carefully the throat the place just after the throat you would see a huge empty space between the flames and wall which should have not existed

at 4:57 I might be wrong, but it appears like it is the gas that ignites. When you add the aniline to the nitric acid, there is clearly a Lewis acid/base reaction that is exothermic. This quickly evaporate the liquid that ignites, probably when it comes into contact with the air.

Then there is too much product in the tube and not enough reactive. So you have to wait a moment while more reactive get evaporated to get the second blast.

I would suggest doing this experiment in an inert environment, maybe with nitrogen gas. This will show is the ignition is cause by the reactives coming into contact with oxygen.

If this is the case, you can then find the right mix of gas to get the most energetic reaction.

You may or have mentioned this in the video (correct me if I’m wrong; I wrote this comment at the beginning) you did not mention Rocket candy. R-Candy, as it is known, is a hypergolic rocket fuel considered a great alternative to gunpowder as a fuel, as it is a paste made from Potassium Nitrate and either pure sucrose or sorbitol. I happened upon a video explaining it with sorbitol, and it appears to be an extremely cheap yet extremely practical way to make amateur rocket fuel. Nitric acid being as dangerous as it is isn’t practical alone but combined with the potassium in KNO3 it is obviously more stable. Hence I also imagined using Ethanol, created also using sucrose, with an obtainable form of liquid oxygen.

A warning when playing with mixtures of concentrated nitric acid and aniline: Make sure your residues are thoroughly diluted with lots of water when cleaning up afterwards, especially from the tubes that didn't ignite. This is due to the other reactions between the aniline and nitric acid. One is a simple acid-base reaction, producing anilinium nitrate, aka phenylammonium nitrate, which is nothing to really worry about.

However, nitric acid doesn't stop there: It also sticks nitro (NO2) groups around the aromatic ring at the ortho and para (2, 4 and 6) positions. You will definitely make nitroaniline and some dinitroaniline, possibly even some trinitroaniline if the nitric acid is in excess. These are all explosive compounds, with a similar behaviour and sensitivity to picric acid. So you don't want to leave them hanging around for too long - they might get frisky at some point and decide to pop off . . . . .

@NileRed, I love your videos, and I have no problem with you deciding to get your videos sponsored by NordVPN, but I find what you say about security online a bit misinformed. Nowadays most reputable and popular social media, banking and mail websites use the SSL protocol. You can know that because the URL starts with https. This means that your device trusts that website because it has provided a valid certificate, and that all data will be encripted using the server's private key. Even if you're on public WiFi, no one but the server and you can know what's in those messages.
Sure, NordVPN can offer extra protection for websites which don't use SSL, but most day to day websites like Gmail, Outlook, Youtube, Facebook, Twitter, Google... all use SSL and are already secure.
Also, I haven't looked into how NordVPN works, but surely it must at some point transfer your data unencripted to the server if the server doesn't use SSL, because otherwise it wouldn't be able to understand it. So, very probably your data gets encripted, sent to NordVPN's network, then decripted and sent to the server.
I'd encourage you to research the topic a bit more. Knowledge is power, and especially IT knowledge in this day and age.

@NileRed You got a pretty good firing with your small diameter throats, but there is an engineering aspect to making the reaction even better. In high power rockets, the divergent side of the nozzle is designed to equilibriate the pressures of the expanding gases to the ambient pressure. I am doubtful you can achieve such precision with off the shelf glassware, but if you want a side project consider looking into stainless steel nozzles or various DIY high power nozzles to attached to the aft end of the reaction vessel.

Also something to note, the reaction in the larger and smaller tubes most likely ignited when the vaporizing gases were at the same volume. That volume can be calculated to best design a combustion chamber which would ultimately react the fuel and oxidizer much more efficiently and produce a longer burn. Just some interesting tips from a studying rocket scientist (:

Awesome test! One hypergolic combination I've tried before was furfuryl alcohol and WFNA. As for hydrazine, I have no experience with that to say whether it is a bad idea given your setup. I would think, though, that the best way to obtain it would be to start with hydrazine sulfate, which is readily available and a pretty safe solid, but which can be easily converted to a solution of plain hydrazine in water. Finally, one small correction regarding the rocket nozzle - you are correct that the convergent nozzle speeds up the gasses from subsonic to supersonic, but what you missed is that supersonic flow has the opposite behavior - letting it expand into a wider cross-section causes it to speed up, not slow down as it would with subsonic flow. So, the divergent part of the nozzle is actually doing the same thing that the convergent part does, just at a different flow speed.

NileRed, if you want thrust, the divergent part of the nozzle only increses the thrust if supersonic. If flow does not reach Mach 1, the divergent part of the nozzle will only slow down the gasses and greatly reduce the thrust.

Hydrazine, really hypergolic fuels in general, isn't used in rockets because of the large amount of noxious fumes released into the area, the danger to those working with it, and the fact that rockets are known to explode before they reach space (see Nedelin catashtrophe - not hydrazine, but definitely hypergolic). Hypergolic fuels' main uses are in thrusters for orbiters/satellites and as a source of ignition for non-hypergolic fuels. Every modern professional/military liquid fueled rocket uses LOX and non-toxic fuel for thrust.

As for your make-shift nozzle, it needs to be specially designed with precise calculations. The throat is supposed to get the exhaust up to the speed of sound using the bernoulli principle. After gasses reach the speed of sound their properties change and you need to expand them in order to get them to move any faster. For different oxidizer/fuel combinations the speed of sound of the exhaust will be different and for different combustion temps it'll take different throat lengths to reach the speed of sound. The shape of the nozzle going into and out of the throat is also very important.

If you're planning on making more liquid fuel rockets, I'd suggest using non-hypergolic fuels for safety and finding specifications for a small liquid rocket engine and copying that to the letter so that you don't have to do any complex calculations in order to get a properly working engine.

So as for the worrying about the neck of the test tube; the size of the throat, shape and size of the bell, and the rate at which the be throat contracts/expands at the bell and chamber are crucial. Part of the reason the rocket engines generate so much thrust is that they are engineered to control where the sonic shock wave happens. This creates resonance in the bell which helps create compression on the exhaust. It's like an even smaller throat created through the bell by high pressure gasses. You can see the effect when you watch some of the pro rockets firing and it looks almost like a flame within a flame. That said, when original rockets were made, before this sonic wave was really discovered and harnessed, a lot of rockets exploded in the faces of scientists, so safety and caution should never be thrown to the wind. I think this could create some interesting effects on the reaction, as it looks like the reaction is moving up through the tube, and the control of the wave would cause back pressure on the "throat" meaning the reaction would only take place within the chamber (and creating a lot more thrust). Please do not mess with Hydrazine, it is incredibly toxic. A fairly small accidental release can put your entire neighborhood in serious harm.

On a lighter note, it looks like your throat needs to be smaller. You need to achieve "choked flow" at the throat for much effectiveness. When properly choked, the speed of gas is Mach 1 and it hits equilibrium and no additional speed is possible. This then allows supersonic physics to kick in and accelerate the gas further down the nozzle. If not choked you are not supersonic and dealing with different equations and not accelerating past Boyle's Law. I have some nozzle design textbooks from college I can scan for you if you want to get something going better, has all the calculations needed.

Also see if you can adapt and afford a "choked flow Venturi". They are typically used for gas flow measurement and are exactly the shape you need if you can adapt to it.

Hydrazine is no joke, only work with it under ventilation. If you can smell a strong ammonia-like odor while you're working with it, you've been exposed to too much. In that circumstance, contain any hydrazine you're working with, leave it under ventilation, and vacate the premises. Otherwise it would be easier to manufacture the derivative fuels than it would be to buy them. They really only have a niche application in aircraft emergency power units, so anyone who isn't in an airport's maintenance supply office would have a hard time getting their hands on those fuels cheaply.

The convergent-divergent nozzle is only useful if it is carefully calculated for the exact combustion conditions.
For it to work, the exhaust gas flow at the choke point must be exactly the speed of sound. Only then will it do what its supposed to, exhalerate the exhaust gas to supersonic speed.
If the combustion conditions are not exactly met to reach mach 1 at the choke, it will just simply act as a venture tube, and the exhaust speed will decrease in the divergent part.

In addition to reaching the ignition point, the reaction is only going to happen on the interface between the two substances, right? So if you've just got the fuel sitting on top of the oxidizer, or vise versa, then the reaction where they meet is going to push them apart. For a thorough reaction, I think the two components need to be distributed as homogenously as possible. Which of course is a race against a very fast clock.

If a boiler flask can withstand the force of the expanding gasses, that might be your best bet. Because then, even though you still have the same problem of the compounds being relatively unmixed, when the reaction kicks them apart, some of that splashing will be bounced back toward the place where it's all happening.
